mainmatter.p: Combining and , we arrive at the following picture. Each family of colors corresponds to the filtration F_ \bullet C_n in one dimension, and the different shades corresponds to the degree in the filtration.

embedded-tex.embedded-tex-preamble: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs} \usetikzlibrary{decorations.pathreplacing}

mainmatter.p: Note that we arranged so that only the higher degree (i.e. the lighter color) components may touch the lower degree components in the next dimension. So the intersection is a triangle shape instead of a complete diamond grid. This corresponds to the requirement that the boundary map sends F_i C_j to F_i C_{j+1}.
We can visualize a filtered object F_1 A \subseteq F_2 A \subseteq F_3 A \subseteq A as nested rectangles.

embedded-tex.embedded-tex-preamble: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs} \usetikzlibrary{decorations.pathreplacing}

mainmatter.p: The graded components of this filtration are the individual rectangular regions.

Since the boundary subgroup in one dimension can also be considered as a quotient in a lower dimension, it may be beneficial to identify the two in a visualization. This leads to the following picture. Regions appearing to the right are to be considered as quotients, and those to the left as subobjects. Further development of this visualization scheme can be seen here.

mainmatter.p: We chose to draw circles to emphasize the individual chain groups. In more complicated situations, it is more convenient to draw a chain of rectangles, with each chain group spanning three rectangular regions. We would then need other means to convey the confines of each object.
